header.title: El Ntuán: Tratado De Nsambia Mpungo (The Secret Of Power)
authors: Rev. Dr. Román S Rodríguez Alegría, MsD (El Brujo)
header.category: Western Esotericism & Occultism, Afro-Cuban Religions (Palo Monte Mayombe Regla Kimbiza Sagrada Sarabanda)
keywords: Palo Monte Mayombe Regla Kimbiza Sagrada Sarabanda

central_thesis: The book presents itself as a foundational esoteric text, 'El Ntuán,' containing the 'Words of the Creator' (Sambi/Nzambi Mpungu). Its central thesis is that ultimate divine power resides within every human being, who is a direct manifestation of the Creator. Through rigorous spiritual study, disciplined practice of specific rituals, chants, and mental exercises (Amuliwa, Umoja), practitioners can awaken and master this inherent 'power of the one' (Ngunsa Yesi). This mastery allows for manifestation of desires, healing, dimensional travel, and ultimately, achieving a state of perfect union with the Creator and immortality, transcending the limitations of the physical world and escaping negative karmic cycles.

structure_content.summary: Establishes humanity's African origins, the antiquity of the monotheistic religion in Africa, and introduces 'El Ntuán' as sacred texts of Bantu spirituality, preserved through oral and written tradition.

structure_content.chapter_title: Muanantu Bambuto (The Beginning & Foundation Of The Religion)
structure_content.summary: Details the creation myth: Nzambi (Creator) made Bantu (father of Humanity), giving him vast land and placing animals and plants. Nzambi instructs Bantu on sacrifice and prayer. Descendants of Bantu form clans. The story of Masilo and Masilonyane's disobedience leading to Masilonyane's death and Nzambi's instruction to create Nganga from his body, marking the birth of Palo Monte Mayombe. Yácara, a later prophet, receives direct revelations from Sarabanda (a Mpungo) and Nzambi, establishing the Kimbiza branch, its teachings, and the importance of positive thought and action.

Outlines core ethical and practical guidelines for initiates, promising salvation, well-being, and happiness through adherence. It details individual 'Tratados' for oaths, commandments, offerings, cabildo ordinances, Sarabandero laws and duties, sacerdotal obligations, and fundamental principles, each containing 21 'Güisá' (teachings).

Explores the fundamental nature of the Creator (Thought as pure energy), the process of creation, the equality of all creation, and the divine spark within each individual. Emphasizes positive thought, action, and the karmic law of 'what you do comes back tenfold'.

Expands on the Creator's nature as both male and female, positive and negative. Introduces the concept of two spirits (positive/negative) within humans, dimensional levels (Munansulu, Lurian Bansa, Kumancongo), and numerical symbolism in creation. Discusses the origin of 'devils' as human creations and the role of Mpungos as eternal spirits.

Focuses on the practitioner's rights and responsibilities. Instructions on chanting to manifest desires, making offerings to Nganga, respect for sacred spaces, and ethical conduct. Emphasizes honesty, courage, and faith in the Creator's presence.

Details the hierarchical structure of the Kimbiza priesthood, from Nkintuala Nkisi (highest) to Tata/Yaya and Hijo/Hija Inkisi, and their roles in guiding the community and representing the Nfumo Bata. Explains the ascending degrees of power within the priesthood and the importance of studying the 'El Ntuán' for enlightenment.

Provides an origin story of humanity, tracing it back to space travelers from a destroyed planet (Adén). Details the early migration to Earth, the establishment of the Bantu tribe, and ancient conflicts. Includes prophecies about global changes and the migration of humans across the Earth.

Explores the concept of energy levels in all creation, from plants to humans, and methods to absorb these energies (e.g., touching with fingertips). Describes different energy levels of sounds and the importance of elements (Earth, Air, Fire, Water) as 'semi-gods.' Offers practical advice on health, healing, and living harmoniously with one's body and nature.

Establishes a deep connection between humans and animals, asserting that humans are owners of their own destiny but not of other creatures. Warns against enslavement, torture, or harm to animals, stating that such actions lead to negative karmic repercussions and reincarnation as lower forms. Emphasizes respect for all creatures as manifestations of the Creator.

Delves into metaphysical questions about creation, eternal life, the structure of reality (hexagrams, Kinyángla), the nature of God as pure thought, other dimensions and planets, and the illusory nature of perceived reality. Explains how thought itself creates reality and that humans possess this creative power.

Focuses on Munansulu (the Creator's abode) and Lurian Bansa (realm of eternal condemnation). Describes the path to Munansulu through righteous living and service, and the consequences of negative actions, which lead to reincarnation and suffering. Highlights specific spiritual gifts from Sambia (telepathy, healing, divination) and warnings against their misuse.

A practical guide to using 'Ndinga' (powerful words/chants) and 'Wangaras' (incantations) for various magical purposes. Provides detailed instructions for rituals, including preparation, specific chants, body postures, and the use of sacred objects like patipembas, pañuelos, and magnetized items for purposes like bringing rain, protection, healing, love, abundance, and enhancing power. Emphasizes positive intent and sincerity.

Describes the divine nature of the priesthood, its purpose to guide humanity, and the different levels of initiation (Hijo/Hija Inkisi, Padre/Madre Inkisi, Tata/Yaya Nganga, Nkintuala Nkisi, Nfumo Bata). Stresses the equality of men and women in the priesthood and the importance of continuous study and spiritual advancement.

Examines human nature, diet, and spiritual well-being. Discusses dietary guidelines (e.g., avoid certain animal parts, moderate fermented juices, moderate smoking) for a long and healthy life. Emphasizes love for all creation as a reflection of love for the Creator and warns against harming one's body. Reaffirms that humans possess inherent creative power.

Explores the interconnectedness of all living things through shared power and colors. Identifies sacred places on Earth where the Creator's power is stronger and warns against places reserved for animals or negative forces. Prophesies a 'Savior' (Nfumo Bata 'Alegría') who will appear to restore truth and combat a 'beast religion' that will enslave humanity, destroying ancestral traditions and the true history of the world. Details signs of these end times.

Reveals esoteric knowledge, including plants for enlightenment and their sacred use. Describes ritualistic naming conventions for initiates (Nguello, Nfumo Bata) and the importance of taking responsibility for what one names. Provides guidance on reading stars for self-knowledge, finding water through natural signs, herbal remedies for snakebites/insect stings, and working with lunar phases for magical operations.

Continues Yácara's narrative in India, detailing the growth of the Kimbiza religion. Explains the seven levels of enlightenment, seven colors of God, seven mystical senses, seven rays of energy, seven master numbers, seven Masters, seven paths to mastery, seven dimensions, seven great animals, seven key places on Earth, and seven seals/doors to unlock spiritual power. Emphasizes the sequential mastery of these elements for spiritual advancement.

structure_content.chapter_title: Muanantu Kumi Isabami (Tratado 16 De Las Curas)
structure_content.summary: An extensive compendium of herbal medicine for various ailments. Lists specific plants (e.g., ginseng, mullein, ginger, eucalyptus, pine, cedar, aloe) and their applications, including teas, poultices, and external rubs, to cure diseases, relieve pain, detoxify, and promote overall health. Provides guidance on preventing illness and maintaining vitality through natural remedies.

structure_content.chapter_title: Muanantu Kumi Isabuare (Tratado 17 De Los Espíritus)
structure_content.summary: Defines ten types of spirits: Power, Intelligence, Wisdom, Love, Justice, Beauty, Principal, Eternity, Good, and Humanity, linking them to cardinal directions and various energies. Explains how power emanates from Sambi and is distributed. Discusses divination systems (Chamalongo, Vititi, tarot, dreams) as means of communication with Mpungos and Nkisis. Illustrates spiritual principles with visual signs/patipembas.

A series of philosophical dialogues and questions, reflecting on human nature, suffering, and the path to wisdom. Covers themes such as the transient nature of wealth, the value of wisdom, the importance of self-reliance, the illusory nature of the physical world, and the eternal aspect of the spirit. Encourages active pursuit of truth and self-improvement.

Chronicles Yácara's continued travels and the expansion of the Kimbiza religion. Details his return to India, the growth of the community, and his decision to pass on leadership. Includes prophecies about future challenges, the role of Nfumo Bata Babatunde, and the ultimate destruction and recreation of the world, with a focus on spiritual survival for the faithful.

Documents Yácara's journey to Western Europe and his interactions with the 'Mindeles' (primitive white tribes). Describes their culture, language barriers, and the initial challenges and eventual success of teaching the Kimbiza religion. Mentions the construction of the 'Templo de Yácara' and early initiates like Ayéenla and Náyade.

structure_content.chapter_title: Muanantu Chichiguma Yesi (Tratado 21 Crónicas De Las Islas)
structure_content.summary: Narrates Yácara's mission in the British Isles (Gaul), describing the indigenous people's way of life and their adoption of Kimbiza. Details the construction of temples and the continued teaching. Includes prophecies of future world changes, the rise of powerful, destructive religions ('beast religion'), and the ultimate triumph of the Brujos and the Ntuán's teachings. Explores the power of pyramids to manipulate time and energy.

Yácara's advanced age and the impending 'transfer' of his role as Nfumo Bata. Prophecies of cataclysmic global shifts, the emergence of an 'Anti-God' figure, and the destruction of the old world. The continuity of the Kimbiza tradition through the succession of Nfumo Bata Babatunde, who is tasked with completing El Ntuán. Emphasizes the Brujo's way of life as positive action, gratitude, and helping others.

structure_content.chapter_title: Muanantu Chichiguma Iyate (Tratado 23 De Las Wangaras)
structure_content.summary: A practical manual for advanced magical operations using 'Wangaras' (chants) for protection against enemies, healing, wealth attraction, love, power enhancement, plant growth, and weather control. Provides specific chants, instructions for offerings, candle colors, and ritualistic actions to achieve desired outcomes. Details the energy modifications induced by sound and intent.

structure_content.chapter_title: Muanantu Chichiguma Iya (Tratado 24 A Través del Tiempo)
structure_content.summary: Delves deeper into the philosophy of destiny, free will, and the creative power of thought. Explains how Sambi created diverse paths for each creature and how one's life is projected through 'ten paths.' Emphasizes aligning with the correct path for positive outcomes and living according to Sambi's teachings to overcome obstacles. Warns against negativity and false gods.

structure_content.chapter_title: Muanantu Chichiguma Ifumo (Tratado 25 El Salvador y El Principe)
structure_content.summary: Recounts the initial peopling of Earth by negative space travelers, leading to the creation of false gods and primitive beliefs. Traces the cyclical nature of societal advancement and decline due to spiritual ignorance. Prophesies the coming of a 'Savior' and 'Prince of Truth' to restore the true religion amidst end-time conflicts and the destruction wrought by misguided human actions. Discusses the ultimate return to the Creator's path.

structure_content.chapter_title: Muanantu Chichiguma Isabami (Tratado 26 Preguntas y Respuestas)
structure_content.summary: Addresses common questions about the Ntuán, its comprehensive nature, the existence of other sacred texts, and the meaning of 'sacred works.' Explains why the teachings encourage positive thought and action before advanced concepts are revealed. Delves into the illusory nature of reality, the concept of the 'one' power (Ngunsa Yesi), and the importance of experience over mere belief in magical practice.

Detailed instructions on 'Amuliwa,' a path to complete control over one's body and mind, leading to manifestation, perfection, and eternal life. Involves extensive meditative and sensory exercises to become aware of and manipulate internal energies. Describes a process of deep relaxation, concentration on body parts, and specialized breathing techniques to stimulate ESP and achieve a trance state for dimensional travel. Emphasizes consistency and dedication.

Detailed instructions on achieving 'Umoja' (union) with all existence, including plants, animals, elements (wind, water), and other humans. This involves projecting one's spirit into these entities, experiencing their sensations, and merging consciousness. Describes this as a profound dimensional journey, highlighting its transformative power for understanding the interconnectedness of all things and gaining mastery over external realities.

structure_content.chapter_title: Muanantu Chichiguma Ifua (Tratado 29 El Secreto Del Poder)
structure_content.summary: Explains the 'power of the one' (Ngunsa Yesi) as the singular, undivided force of the Creator, present within all things. Discusses how this power can be divided into positive, negative, and neutral aspects by human perception and used for various ends. Emphasizes positive thought and action for effective use of power and offers a ritual for neutralizing negative influences. Warns against misusing this inherent power, as it can lead to self-destruction.

The path to becoming a 'Master,' asserting that the individual is inherently divine ('Yo Soy dios'). Emphasizes achieving 'Umoja' (union) with all creation and the Creator as the ultimate goal. Outlines ethical principles: freedom for creatures, helping the poor, forgiving wrongs, and spreading truth. Defines the Master as one who embodies Umoja, possesses all power, wisdom, and can manifest desires without external rituals.

Dedicated to 'MAMBI,' a divine entity representing eternal life and wisdom. Introduces 'Silaimose,' a sacred rite for dimensional travel and acquiring knowledge of all mysteries. Describes Maumau as a principal city and the construction of Cabildos (temples) for honoring MAMBI. Details practices for achieving trance states and experiencing other dimensions through chanting and meditation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Muanantu Makumatatu Yole (Tratado 32 De Los Amos o Maestros)
structure_content.summary: Distinguishes between 'negative' and 'positive' actions on the path to mastery. Negative actions include honoring others above oneself, fanaticism, gossiping, revenge, hoarding wealth, enslavement, unjust laws, consuming intoxicants, and harming creatures. Positive actions involve helping others, creating beauty, sharing wisdom, fulfilling promises, being patient, loving all creation, and using power for collective good.

structure_content.chapter_title: Muanantu Makumatatu Iyate (Tratado 33 El Gran Cambio Mundial)
structure_content.summary: Prophecies about impending global changes, social unrest, and natural disasters. Provides practical advice for survival: stockpiling food, medicine, tools, and choosing safe locations away from cities. Emphasizes the importance of the Nganga and primitive tools. Warns about signs of change, such as gun confiscation and the abolition of physical money in favor of electronic systems, leading to control over citizens.

key_concepts.definition: The sacred texts or 'Words of the Creator' (Sambi/Nzambi Mpungu), containing divine wisdom, laws, rituals, and prophecies for humanity.

The Creator, conceived as pure, unisexual thought or energy, the ultimate source of all existence, both positive and negative. It is all-encompassing, within everything, and is the ultimate power. Humans are manifestations of Sambi.
Divine spirits or divine forces, created by Sambi, who serve as guides and mediators for humanity, often associated with specific elements or domains.

A sacred altar or cauldron, considered the 'voice of the Creator on earth' and a vessel of spiritual power. Also refers to a high-ranking priest or priestess in the Palo Monte tradition. Central to rituals and offerings.
A specific branch or 'Regla' of Palo Monte Mayombe, characterized by its teachings derived from El Ntuán and its hierarchical spiritual structure.
A specific Mpungo, identified as the spirit of truth and an intermediary of the Creator, who transmitted key teachings to Yácara.
A prophet and high priest chosen by Nzambi to receive and disseminate the teachings of El Ntuán, considered the founder of the Kimbiza tradition.
The highest title in the Kimbiza priesthood, signifying an absolute spiritual leader, prophet, and father/mother of the people. This is a position of immense power and responsibility.
High priests/priestesses, literally 'blood brothers/sisters of man,' who form a holy council governing the community and affairs of the faith, from whom the Nfumo Bata is chosen.
Priests ('Tata' for men, 'Yaya' for women) in the Kimbiza hierarchy, who lead tribes and teach the traditions.
A specific teaching, word of wisdom, or instruction from the Creator or a divine entity within El Ntuán. The term also means 'listen' or 'understand'.
The Creator's abode or realm, described as a perfect dimension of eternal peace, happiness, and unlimited power, where perfected beings reside.
A realm of darkness, suffering, and eternal condemnation for those who choose a negative path and misuse their inherent power.
An intermediate realm or dimension of waiting and purification before reincarnation or ascension to Munansulu.
The physical dimension of Earth, perceived as illusory compared to higher dimensions.
A state of perfect union, oneness, and complete control over all things, achieved through deep spiritual practice and alignment with the Creator. It is the ultimate power.

A method or training regimen focused on achieving complete control over one's own body and mind, enabling manifestation of desires and ultimately, eternal life and perfection. It involves deep breathing, sensory awareness, and mental concentration.
The 'power of the one,' the ultimate, singular, inherent power residing within every individual, enabling creation and control over reality. It is the force that Sambi himself embodies.
Powerful and secret words, divine in origin, used in rituals to control elements and manifest specific outcomes.
Chants or incantations, often repetitive, used in conjunction with Ndingas and rituals to generate specific energies and achieve magical effects.
Sacred signatures or symbols, each with specific meanings and energies, used in rituals for various purposes (protection, healing, etc.).
A rare and sacred rite of dimensional travel, a trance state that allows exploration of other dimensions and the acquisition of universal knowledge, leading to union with MAMBI and Kadiampembe.

practical_system.description: The practical system revolves around harnessing the inherent 'power of the one' (Ngunsa Yesi) within each individual, which is believed to be a fragment of the Creator's own thought-energy. This is achieved through a multi-faceted approach combining spiritual understanding, ethical living, and specific magical techniques. The ultimate goal is to attain 'Umoja' (perfect union with all existence and the Creator) and 'Amuliwa' (complete mastery over one's body, mind, and external reality), leading to immortality and the ability to manifest desires. The system is presented as a continuous path of learning and practice, with increasing levels of understanding and power.
tools: Candles (various colors, including red, white, yellow, green, purple, black)
Incense (fresa, cereza wood, pine, sandalwood, frankincense, uva wood)
Pañuelos (handkerchiefs) of specific colors for ritual purposes
Cáliz Ero (silver or metal cup for water)
Piedra imán (lodestone) and various crystals (e.g., sapphire, ruby, emerald, topacio, amatista, oro, plata, cuarzo) for attracting energies, protection, and healing
Herbs, roots, barks, and seeds for medicinal and magical uses (e.g., ginseng, mullein, ginger, eucalyptus, pine, cedar, aloe, cayenne, valerian, wormwood, mandrake root, oak bark)
Chamalongo (divination system using coconut shells, cowries, or bones)
Vititi Mensu (a horn charged with magical properties for seeing all things)
Ntongo Ero (staff or 'Palo de muerto' with a crystal for attracting solar energy)
La Cruz Ansata/Ankh (symbol of life power)
Escarabajo (scarab, symbol of the Creator, moves the earth)
Hexagram (six-pointed star, symbolizes complete power of Sambi)
rituals: Ndinga and Wangara Chanting: Repetitive recitation of powerful, sacred words and incantations to generate specific energies and manifest desired outcomes. Instructions include specific phrases, numbers of repetitions, and vocal tones (e.g., for rain, protection, love, wealth, healing).

Patipemba (Signatures) Usage: Drawing and utilizing specific sacred symbols for various ritual purposes, believed to align with cosmic forces and divine entities. Explicit instructions are given for placement and intent.

Offerings and Sacrifices: Presenting specific items (animals, objects) to the Nganga or Mpungos to express gratitude, seek favor, and generate reciprocal energy exchanges. Money is also considered a necessary offering for services.
Body Postures and Directions: Assuming specific stances (e.g., 'star position'), facing cardinal directions (east, north, south, west), and extending hands for rituals to align with cosmic energies.

Meditation and Concentration: Focused mental exercises, including deep relaxation, concentrating awareness on specific body parts (e.g., left big toe), or visualizing white walls to clear the mind and enhance inner perception (part of Amuliwa).

Dimensional Travel (Silaimose/Umoja): Advanced practices involving astral projection or forceful projection of one's spirit into plants, animals, elements (wind, water, fire), other humans, or other dimensions. This is achieved through deep trance states and intense concentration, with the goal of experiencing universal oneness.

Amuliwa Exercises: A comprehensive regimen for self-mastery, including deep breathing techniques to stimulate ESP, 'knowledge training' for internal body awareness, stretching, 'fire dance' (rhythmic movement), and specific massage techniques to maintain youthfulness and bodily control.

Pyramid Power: Utilization of pyramid shapes (houses, chambers, even hats) and specific crystals to manipulate cosmic energies, influencing time (accelerating or retarding aging) and promoting health or specific outcomes based on the shape of objects struck by cosmic rays.

Color Magic: Deliberate use of specific colors (e.g., red for love/power, white for purity/blessings, green for growth/protection, blue for thought-energy, yellow for riches/joy) in clothing, candles, and ritual objects to attract and channel corresponding energies.

Herbal Medicine and Magic: Extensive use of plants, roots, barks, and seeds for healing (e.g., ginseng for general health, eucalyptus for fever/asthma, pine for lung issues) and various magical purposes, often involving teas, cataplasms, or ritualistic placement.

relevant_quotes.text: GÜISÁ 10. Al llega a la tribu ya Masilonyane estaba muy mal y no duro mucho tiempo y murió por las heridas y la enfermedad y Bantu corrió a la montaña donde estaba Dios y Nzambi le dijo; Has una Nganga con el cuerpo de Masilonyane y que este Nkisi tendrá la fuerza para curar o matar, y te dará remedio a tus males, ahí debería hacer sus sacrificio y dar sus ofrendas por siempre y yo vendré para ayudarte cuando tengas problemas, pero debes ser obediente y de ahora en lo adelante y por siempre deberán rayarse y con su sangre jurar su obediencia a mi Nzambi, y así todos recordaran sus juramentos. Así nació la primera religión o Regla de Palo Monte Mayombe.

GÜISÁ 14. Un espíritu se había materializado de repente en la forma de un hombre bonito y fuerte hablo a Yácara y le dijo que no tuviera miedo que el había sido enviado por el Creador para decirle la verdad de todas las cosas. El dijo que su nombre era Sarabanda y que el era un mpungo, un espíritu divino que vive en la morada del Creador, Dios Supremo, Omnipotente y Omnisciente y que Yácara había sido escogido para llevar a las personas de toda la tierra a fuera del camino de oscuridad e ignorancia.

GÜISÁ 23. Yo soy Nsambia, el Creador. Yo te he seleccionado, Yácara, para ser mi mensajero de esta tierra, ir por toda la tierra y extender la verdad de todas las cosas. Entre las tribus y las personas de la tierra muchas enseñanzas buenas y muchas religiones buenas hay, pero ellos no saben la verdad de todas las cosas, por consiguiente ve por toda la tierra y les enseñan las cosas que yo te instruiré. Yo hice todo lo que hay, y he hecho todo perfecto, y significa que el hombre debe mantener todo perfecto, y también le di el Poder al hombre para hacer con el mundo como él le plazca. Si haces las cosas positivas, sólo cosas positivas vendrán a ti, y vendrá a ti diez veces. Si haces las cosas negativas, sólo cosas negativas vendrán a ti y volverán diez veces. No sólo debes actuar positivo, pero debes pensar positivo también, pues tus pensamientos solos, son poderosos.

GÜISÁ 1. En el principio Había la Energía. El Pensamiento era la pura energía. El Pensamiento pensó en si mismo, y supo quién era, y supo que estaba solo. El Pensamiento pensó en otras cosas. Soñó los sueños, y los sueños se volvieron las cosas. El Pensamiento conoció su Poder, y pensó más cosas, y todo lo que el Pensamiento pensó, se materializo. Y todo lo que hay, el Pensamiento Pensó, y se materializo.

GÜISÁ 28. El hombre que niega que el es dios es un tonto. No deje a ningún hombre negarle que usted es dios, el único dios. GÜISÁ 21. Nunca niegue a ninguna criatura que usted es dios. Sepa en si mismo íntimo que usted es de hecho dios.

GÜISÁ 3. Hay realmente un poder del uno, un poder que es una fuerza, una energía que se llame el Ngunsa Yesi que significa “poder del uno”. Esta energía del uno es la única poder que hay y cuando esta energía se divide, entonces se convierte en una fuerza negativa y positiva, dos fuerzas. Cuando usted va entre estas dos fuerzas y utiliza un poco de ambas igualmente que se llama Ambiata y es dicho que usted está utilizando Ambiata. Cuando usted utiliza la fuerza del uno o la fuerza dividida pues la fuerza es realmente usted, usted es el Prava de si. Usted es el amo de esta fuerza entonces Prava significa el “amo de la fuerza”, por lo tanto si usted domina el arte de usar esta fuerza del uno sin dividirla, usted es el Prava de si.
GÜISÁ 19. El camino hacia mí, es por las cosas que yo te enseño. GÜISÁ 20. El amor hacia otros es la manera a Munansulu y la manera al gran poder.

GÜISÁ 101. En épocas antiguas la gente de la tierra sabía de esto y ella construyó muchos de sus casas en la forma de la pirámide para obtener la buena salud y vida larga, pues la forma de la pirámide e invierte el tiempo, de modo que fuera al revés. Todo el espacio dentro de la creación es rodeado por estas vigas cósmicas. Si estas vigas se cambian en su dirección, las nuevas cosas se crean, o la creación del presente envejece, según las formas que golpean, puede hacer acelerar el envejecimiento o retrasar. Cuando golpean un objeto redondo, se retrasa el envejecer. Si golpean un objeto cuadrado, el proceso del envejecimiento se apresura. Si golpean cualesquiera formas irregulares, el proceso del envejecimiento se puede apresurar o retrasar, según la forma.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book, 'El Ntuán,' is presented as a foundational and comprehensive text for Palo Monte Mayombe Regla Kimbiza Sagrada Sarabanda, an Afro-Cuban religious and magical tradition. It contextualizes the religion's origins, cosmology, ethics, and practical magic within a grand narrative of creation, human evolution, and cosmic cycles. The claim that this tradition predates and underpins many other world religions and belief systems (including aspects of ancient Egypt, India, Tibet, and even a critique of Christianity) is a common assertion in esoteric literature seeking to establish antiquity and supreme authority. The emphasis on inner power, manifestation through thought, and personal responsibility aligns with currents in modern Western Esotericism, particularly Chaos Magic's subjective belief systems and Gnostic ideas of self-divinization. The prophecies of future world changes, the rise of a 'beast religion,' and the ultimate triumph of the Brujos resonate with apocalyptic and millenarian themes found in various occult and religious traditions.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience is primarily initiates and serious practitioners of Palo Monte Mayombe Regla Kimbiza Sagrada Sarabanda. The text is dense, requires extensive study ('many years'), and contains secrets revealed only to initiates ('Se le dirá después de su iniciación aquí con nosotros'). It is also aimed at individuals interested in the theoretical and practical aspects of Afro-Cuban religions, comparative esotericism, and operative magic who are seeking a comprehensive spiritual system. The warnings against misuse of power and the detailed, step-by-step instructions for rituals indicate an audience committed to ethical and disciplined practice, rather than casual curiosity.
